abstracts.cdata!:
This is a regional environmental
            assessment for the Senegal Casamance Emergency
            Reconstruction Support Project, which identifies the
            environmental and social potential of the Casamance, in
            terms of land and water resources, in biodiversity and in
            marine resources, and presents a regional analysis of the
            degradation of these natural resources. The analysis further
            demonstrates the detrimental impact of currently ongoing,
            resource degradation and its socioeconomic consequence; and
            identifies all pertinent positive and negative impacts
            expected of program interventions. Project interventions
            comprise demining, demobilization, community development,
            and reconstruction. Of the four, the component supporting
            reconstruction and rehabilitation of non-community
            infrastructures may have major negative impacts-although
            this component could have a distinct positive impact when
            correcting existing infrastructure problems. General risks
            concern the overexploitation of forest resources; accidents
            connected with demining; conflicts over land use, especially
            between farmers and herders, and newcomers and residents;
            social and political discrimination; the spread of sexually
            transmitted diseases-particularly HIV/AIDS; disappearing
            species and the loss of habitats; flooded lands;
            agro-chemical pollution of water and soil from pesticides;
            soil salinity, sedimentation, and erosion; increase of
            water-borne illnesses; air pollution caused by dust from
            solid and liquid waste disposal; transformation and
            destruction of coastal areas and mangrove areas because of
            shrimp production;  Mitigation measures will include
            rehabilitating degraded natural habitats; construction and
            rehabilitation of anti-salinity dikes; involving the
            population in improving land management; and institutional
            measures that improve knowledge of biodiversity and
            environmental management, evaluate natural resources,
            regulate their uses, and put in place measures for their
            conservation; and training, information, and awareness
            building measures. Also recommended is supplementary project
            financing from the GEF Operational Program on sustainable
            land management in order to further improve the land
            resource base of the Casamance.
